repnme.cdata!:
Paraguay - Private Sector Development and
            El Nino Project

abstracts.cdata!:
This Implementation Completion Report
            (ICR), relates to the new part B of the project, that
            addressed the emergency related to El Nino; a separate ICR
            for the Private Sector Development phase (Part A) was issued
            on March 23, 2001. It is reiterated that in emergency
            situations, where a rapid response from the Bank is needed,
            the use of an existing loan is often likely to be the most
            appropriate mechanism to achieve responsiveness. The
            assessment of outcome is satisfactory, sustainability
            likely, though the institutional development impact, only
            modest. Lessons suggest that following the emergency,
            reconstruction works, particularly those involving large
            capital investments, and operation and maintenance
            requirements, should be carefully appraised, subject to the
            same technical, economic, financial, and institutional
            analysis as for similar investments. And, during
            implementation of similar projects, the Government should
            avoid shifting responsibilities to other agencies during the
            course of project execution, whereas a clear agreement on
            responsibilities for project implementation at inception,
            would both facilitate the likelihood for follow-up, and
            sustainability after project completion. It is recommended
            that countries with El Nino type phenomena experiences,
            should undertake contingency planning, and preventive
            measures, while many of these types of investments should be
            incorporated in regular sector investment programs, during
            non-emergency periods.

1945957.trustfund: TF029240-PHRD-ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGEMENT PROJECT,TF035370-KENYA - ENVIRONMENTAL PROJECT,TF025390-PRIVATE SECTOR DEVELOPMENT

abstracts.cdata!:
Overall, the project outcome was
            unsatisfactory. However results were mixed, for although
            private sector strengthening, produced outputs in terms of
            relevant outcome indicators, the quality of these outcomes
            was inadequate. Hence, sustainability is rated unlikely,
            though institutional development impacts are modest.
            Furthermore, while the performance of the borrower is
            unsatisfactory, based on the weak preparation efforts
            stemming from the lack of consensus within the Government,
            the Bank performance is rated satisfactory, not only because
            of sound project preparation, and supervision, but because
            of its responsiveness to, and understanding of the
            Government's concerns. Two main lessons are learned
            from this project. 1) New laws, and regulations are not
            sufficient to produce effective policy changes, particularly
            when political powers, will not enforce them. The
            Government's commitment to financial reforms was
            largely subdued, illustrated in the form of delays in
            submitting, and approving new banking legislation,
            aggravated by the reluctance to apply legislation timely,
            and consistently. 2) Effective strengthening of the
            financial sector, legal, and regulatory framework should
            precede any credit line operation, not merely accompany it,
            and, credit lines should not use public banks as financial
            intermediaries. The project demonstrates the high risks
            posed by a credit line operation, in a country with a weak
            banking system, poor regulatory framework, and thriving
            political influences.
